thread.title: Shirts printed to mark year since Marysville-Pilchuck HS...
thread.title_full: Shirts printed to mark year since Marysville-Pilchuck HS... | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: Shirts printed to mark year since Marysville-Pilchuck HS...
text:
Students at Marysville-Pilchuck High School say they will not be defined by the shooting that killed five of their classmates and injured a sixth last year.
It will have been one year since that tragedy on Saturday.
Instead of that, though, MPHS hopes you’ll think of this: #MPstronger.
PHOTOS: MPHS Strong — Community heals after school shooting
Stronger every day – that’s why the hashtag on the T-shirts being printed to mark the anniversary of the deadly shooting doesn’t just say “strong.” They’re free to every student and staff member at MPHS.
The shirts are the culmination of a year’s worth of healing — but there’s more. Students are invited to wear them on Saturday when they’ll be joining the community for a memorial walk, 1.6 miles around the entire school campus.
“The students felt very strongly that they wanted to do something active so we’ll have the bulbs available for planting and then actually go on the walk together,” explains Tara Mizell.
Some 10,000 tulip bulbs – to be planted in the stadium. Rochelle Lubbers and Tara Mizell are both part of the Marysville Tulalip Recovery Committee; Rochelle represents the tribe, Tara the city. They’ve spent the last year holding recovery-related events like suicide prevention training.
“I worked in the community for over 20 years, my husband is a firefighter here in town,” says Tara.
“Born and raised in this community like many people who live here and work here and recreate here,” says Rochelle.
“There’s no way for it not to be a personal event,” agrees Tara. But both say the tragedy and the somber anniversary is most personal for the students who not only survived but overcame it.
“Each day we get a little bit stronger,” concludes Tara.
The shirts cost $10 each and they're so popular the recovery committee already needs to print more of them. They'll be for sale Wednesday through Friday at Lasting Impressions in Marysville.
